data.text: Do Hotels Allow You to Bring Your Bike in?
Do most hotels allow you to bring your bike into the room?
In Mexico no problem In Japan big problem.
data.author: Yossy Matsuda

data.text: Am interested in this question also from a European perspective.From what I have gleaned from similar inquiries, it seems like no problem in Spain, but is more of an issue in France. Haven‚Äôt really heard any info on other countries, but hopefully someone will give wider answers.
data.author: Kevin McCarthy

data.text: France is not a problem. Most hotels have a secured and covered storage place. The only time I had an issue was in the B&B Hotels in Nancy where they did not allow me to store my bike inside although there was enough space for multiple bikes in the corridor next to the stairs.
data.author: Eric Vanbellen

data.text: In germany they usually don't allow it
data.author: Berit Drieschner

data.text: But they usually have a secure place you can park it.
data.author: Cindy C. Rogers

data.text: In the USA most motels do.
data.author: Kris Siejko

data.text: In USA generally not a problem.
data.author: Greg Morath

data.text: In my experience in Australia, the US, UK, France, Italy, Germany - often yes, and if no a secure place was provided (basement, or storage area, shed f some sort) - always locked the bike to itself if nothing else in these places and never had a problem.
data.author: Elizabeth Cage

data.text: The Scarlet Singapore certainly does! No questions
data.author: Pradeep Mehra

data.text: We had no issue in Europe.
data.author: Grant Griffin

data.text: In the USA I‚Äôve never seen one that won‚Äôt
data.author: David Jasmund

data.text: Depends ...
data.author: Kamera Mann

data.text: Only place I‚Äôve been so far that didn‚Äôt allow it was Cuba. But most accommodations there were like B&B‚Äôs in private residences. Most of them did provided me with somewhere semi-safe to lock it but putting it in the room was a no-go.
data.author: Daniel Christianson

data.text: Netherlands, Belgium, France, Germany, denmark, Austria, Luxemburg, Switzerland, never had a Problem...i am wondering if Spain does ... anyone Knows ??
data.author: Enrique Cabral Perez

data.text: Some hotels in Spain do, some don't. Many in popular cycling area have dedicated cycle storage rooms.
data.author: Peter South
Mindy Wong

data.text: If you can't get a safe placae in the hotel for your bike, go to another place and let them know about it.
data.author: Andrea Collisson

data.text: I'm just finishing a tour taking in Germany, Austria, Czechia, Slovakia Hungary and Serbia. No problems yet. It will also help if it's clean.
data.author: Colin Howard

data.text: IN asia and se asia YES/
data.author: Richard Reitman

data.text: In Africa is like 50-50. Some allow the bikes in the room, some would find a place for it somewhere else. In some cases is not practical to take the bike with you, narrow stairs or room to small ...
data.author: Marcu Bogdan Gabriel

data.text: Premier inn and Travelodge in the U.K. do
data.author: Barnaby Taylor

data.text: At the Hyatt Regency in Bali, Indonesia, the concierge will roll your bike into an air-conditioned luggage room near the lobby and tag it. It's my fault for chosing a suite so far away, you have to call for a golf cart to the room and anywhere else. $600 a night does wonders, but the GM is an old school friend so....
data.author: Chris Wee

data.text: Like the majority of traveling cyclists, I don't go into 'general public' hotels for less than $1000 a night (air conditioning for the bike is not an option) and personally, I prefer to be carried by servants rather than borrowing a 'golf cart' to get around.
data.author: Didier Pierre

data.text: but the golf cart comes with a nice female driver and the luggage room has AC as well as mineral water....prior to this hotel I 'suffered' a lot riding 30 days in the mountains of Indonesia .... üôÇ
data.author: Chris Wee

data.text: I hope I will get a nice male driver to ogle at next time I check into the Hyatt Regency. I know these employees just love being treated as decoration by the guests, if they didn't they would get another job, right?
data.author: Vera Van De Nieuwenhof

data.text: staff strength/numbers at this Hyatt is a mind boggling 450 people....!
data.author: Chris Wee

data.text: No
data.author: Martin Mastalka

data.text: I've mostly traveled in Asia and always carried it inside the room without asking and it's rarely an issue. Sometimes I got offered a 'safe' space in a parking lot with a camera but ultimately I sleep better with my expensive bike in my room. If it's dirty I'll clean it outside and I make sure to leave my room spotless so they'll be happy to welcome cyclists again. I had to leave it outside once at a UK hotel with snooty owners and found out in the morning that someone had tried to break the lock, so I'm never doing that again.
data.author: Vera Van De Nieuwenhof

data.text: how "expensive"
data.author: Bert R. Oreta

data.text: about 3500 USD, but the emotional value is much higher :)
data.author: Vera Van De Nieuwenhof

data.text: Why does the actual value matter? I love that bike because of all the trips we shared, it's taken me halfway around the world and I don't want another one. I would be heartbroken if it got stolen. I would also hate to have to deal with the hassle of a bike trip suddenly being without a bicycle, going to the police station etc etc.
data.author: Vera Van De Nieuwenhof

data.text: I've kept the advice that I once got close to heart: 'help to keep honest people honest'. That is, don't tempt others to take what isn't theirs by leaving your bicycle unlocked or unsupervised. It's ultimately your own responsibility to keep it safe. I don't want to give that responsibility to hotel owners who may be careless and who won't have to deal with the hassle if it gets stolen. Also, I cycle through areas where people may have an annual income that is less than the value of my bicycle. They may not recognize it as valuable but I still don't need to have it sitting outside at night, tempting people's honesty ;)
data.author: Vera Van De Nieuwenhof

data.text: Thats true, certain things are price less because of the emotional bond. Rightly explained. Bike safety assumes importance when you are on a long trip. The adventure will be ruined if you lose it. Take bike safety seriously is the essence of the whole conversation.
data.author: Pradeep Kotnala

data.text: exactly.
data.author: Bert R. Oreta

data.text: I once stayed in a hotel in Puno southern Peru. Had to get into something of a showdown with the check-in desk employees to be allowed to take my bike into my room. Later that night two other cyclists showed up with really expensive Rohloff equipped bikes. Management had them store bikes in the "locked" office. Next morning both bikes were gone. At least a $10,000 heists.... probably 5 years worth of salary for a Peruvian. Desk clerk from previous day was suddenly "on vacation and out of town". Sad ending to the couple's around the world plans. I always sleep with my bike.
data.author: Madhavananda Das Brssm

data.text: I always demand to bring my bike to the room, but since it's foldamle in worst case I fold it and put it in its bad then they can't deny.
data.author: Bj√∂rn Lund√©n

data.text: I'm not surprised that you had a problem in the UK. Hatred of cyclists is encouraged by the billionaire-owned right wing press here. It's ridiculous - a bike has a smaller footprint than your shoes and takes almost no space in a room. You wouldn't be expected to leave other personal possessions outside in the car park.
data.author: Jon Mathias

data.text: I know... I've had motorists shake their fist and scowl at me, for no other reason than being on 'their' road with a bicycle. I usually throw them handkisses and big smiles back, which only seems to enrage them further. I really don't get it! But yes, this similar attitude was alos held by the hotel owners. Left them a frank review, especially since they didn't care about the near-theft of my bicycle at all when I told them in the morning.
data.author: Vera Van De Nieuwenhof

data.text: I'm in France right now and the attitude to cyclists vs the UK is chalk and cheese. I've just booked a flat for tonight and the landlord has allowed me to take my bike inside. The bike itself cost over ¬£3k and the luggage, camping equipment and personal stuff on it the same again. Hostile hoteliers are missing a trick. Same with cycling in France vs the UK. No aggression or close passes, much more cycling infrastructure and there are very few of those ludicrous SUVs either. Lots of French folk cycle but they don't wear helmets or lycra or run drop bars - they are mostly on hybrids or Dutch bikes and cycling is seen as just a normal, healthy way to get around.
data.author: Jon Mathias

data.text: I know in Germany they do or at least have a safe place for them
data.author: Derek Clark

data.text: Lol I don't even ask. Bike stays with me at all times.
data.author: R Tucker Cullum

data.text: Depends a lot on your destination. I have found that in countries like Vietnam, Cambodia, The Philippines and Indonesia, this was almost always doable. On the other end of the scale, hotels in the Middle East are often not very happy about it. My guess is that it has to do with most hotels having carpets on the floors. Good news is that it's one of the parts of the world where theft is very uncommon. In western Europe it's a little 50/50 in my opinion. But most of those who do not like that you take the bike in to your room, often has an inside place where you can park it securely. Roadside hotels in Latinamerica usually allows it. But now always city hotels, where you sometimes need to talk a little to them to make them understand that you not not want to park out in the street. But you can always sort something out in Latinamerica. Normally they are very flexible with their hotels in that part of the world, I find.
data.author: Claus Andersen

data.text: Surprising idea. It never occured to me to ask that. I travel in Europe and it's half/ half - i'm either pointed to a place where bikes are stored like garage/ ski storage/ shed, or I just lock it up at the car park. Never had a bad experience.
data.author: Ania EL

data.text: Amsterdam was a no for me which is kind of ironic because its a bike capital of Europe.
data.author: Roman Morozov

data.text: its the capital for the "rusty street city bikes", not any other disciplines apparently üôÑ
data.author: Mindaugas Jokubonis

data.text: I guess it depends where you stay - if it's a hostel will limited indoor space (Amsterdam buildings can be very narrow with steep stairwells) I can say they would say no because they simply can't accommodate it. But hopefully they would offer a secure bike space if they can't take it inside! there are plenty of other disciplines, have a look at what's cycling around in the weekend: upmarket road bikes, cargo bikes with kids in the front, older people enjoying a ride with e-bikes etc etc. If you have only seen rusty bikes you may have been staying in the wrong neighbourhood, or last visited in the '90's ;)
data.author: Vera Van De Nieuwenhof

data.text: I stayed at a hotel. Staff was very unfriendly and they were afraid that I would damage the elevator with my bike. There was plenty of room. They wanted me to keep my 6,000 euro bike on the street. It was very stressful and it wasn't a cheap hotel... its the worst experience I had in European hotel stay.
data.author: Roman Morozov

data.text: No. Especially the Columbus hotel in Oban. Do not ever stay there. Worse than faulty towers
data.author: Matt Duxbury

data.text: not as funny either?
data.author: Kate Schwarz

data.text: certainly not. Never seen anything like it.
data.author: Matt Duxbury

data.text: Motels in nz do
data.author: Rachel Katherine

data.text: Depends. Region, ***** and the people you directly interact with. So, there is probably not the answer more a sum of experience of the crowd.
data.author: Andreas Choffat ChoffatundCo

data.text: In Europe i always ask upfront if i can park my bike somewhere indoors. In 95% they have either a special bike shed or garage, or they let me and my group (8-15 people usually) park in a storage room, a meeting room etc. In the few cases they can not offer this, i book a different hotel, or just tell the receptionist that we take our bike into our room since they could not offer us a better solution. Then they suddenly have a storage room anyway! Taking your bike into your room makes a mess in the room, i understand why hotels dont like that.
data.author: Henk Wesselink

data.text: Depends on the hotel, small independent places I usually ask and they usually offer to keep it in the left luggage room or some other storage. Big chains like Marriot, Premier Inn, Holiday Inn, just walk straight through reception to the room and I've never been stopped.
data.author: Samuel Parkinson

data.text: No
data.author: Wayne Macdougall

data.text: No not most but many! Many really do understand, most go the extra distance to accommodate your needs as best they can , some seriously don‚Äôt. I always asked first before committing. I stayed in a hotel in Japan where my bike was put on display in the reception area with a sign explaining who I was and what I was doing ( no one and nothing spectacular) and people took genuine interest. Bicycles inspire!
data.author: Simon Dodding

data.text: Yet another vague and pointless question.
data.author: Donald Canard

data.text: never a problem in any region - it always works when you interact friendly with everyone!
data.author: Tobias Riegel

data.text: One of the many advantages to touring on Brompton is that it‚Äôs so easy to take into a room, never an issue. Personally I wouldn‚Äôt trust the supposedly secure bike storage some of our big bike friends have been offered in hotels whilst on tour. But the other issue is in some city hotels space is that precious they don‚Äôt have a suitable secure place for a full size bike and the cheaper rooms are too small to conveniently store two bikes.
data.author: Kevan Tracey Rose

data.text: yes
data.author: Vincent Goss

data.text: You're paying for the space you can bring whatever you damn well please in there
data.author: Derek Burgmeier

data.text: If they dont i dont stay
data.author: Mark Steenson

data.text: Just booked into a hotel in muar Malaysia on the 7th floor. Just wheeled my bike fully loaded into the lift.üòÉ
data.author: Creaky Cranks

data.text: Never had the need. Either there is a bike parking or a basement where the bike can be securely stored away.
data.author: Axel Knobbe

data.text: Never had a problem in the US.
data.author: Marcy Kelley

data.text: Every hotel i have ever stayed at with my bike has allowed me to bring it in.
data.author: Angela M Freeman

data.text: I believe that there's a thread on Instagram dedicated to this very thing #bikesinhotelrooms
data.author: Tim Ives

data.text: Just been on a 8 week trip to the Nord Kapp and back, stayed in hotels the majority let keep your bike in the room the rest had a cycle storage space
data.author: Ian Weatherill

data.text: If the hotels have lifts check the size. I arrived at nearly midnight from a ferry and found the reception on the 1st floor with a tiny lift to get my heavily laden bike in.
data.author: Theresa Finking

data.text: Some don‚Äôt over a poor understanding of maths. They think the tires will dirty their floors. But the contact patch is smaller than the sole of a baby‚Äôs shoe. I think it only makes sense to refuse the bikes if they insist that guests put all of their shoes in a common storage area next to the water heaters.
data.author: Louis-Eric Simard

data.text: If they don't, just walk away and find another hotel ! USA, Mexico, Central America, Colombia, we never had a problem! And we have 2 fully loaded bikes.
data.author: Edina Niksz

data.text: I never ask
data.author: George W. Myers
Kyros Moutsouris

data.text: The ONE time I forgot to, it was stolen in Denver. Last year, July.
data.author: OtherLander Freedom Seeker

data.text: In Ukraine - usually don't, but you can leave it somewhere in their storage rooms
data.author: Artem  Bondarenko

data.text: ALL the ones I stay at doüòè
data.author: John MacPherson

data.text: The few I have, did!
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: In Korea they usually do though I've been asked to put it in a storage room a couple times.
data.author: Brian Grover

data.text: I travel with a folding bike and a zipable bag. So far no trouble with any transport or accommodation.
data.author: Guy Lancaster

data.text: I was refused in Lisbon hostel (shit place, anyway) and Dubai. In Dubai they hate bicycles!!! So I hate Dubai too!!! :-))))
data.author: Beggard Beggar

data.text: I always check in with my bike anytime I book my self in an hotel and my bike sleep next to my bed, she is part of my family.
data.author: Monique Chipeta

data.text: In the US, chain hotels, even luxury hotels like Ritz Carlton, let you bring your bike in the room. But independent budget hotels and B&Bs do not.
data.author: Geoffrey Silverstein

data.text: People bring all sorts of things into hotel rooms. I‚Äôd be shocked if a hotel receptionist disallowed a bike in the room. The one exception would be if the bike and/or tires are dirty, thus making more work for housekeeping.
data.author: Gabe Lucas

data.text: I have a motorized bike that I bring in any motel room I'm at granite I'm in the US I rented the room to keep me and my stuff safe I'm bringing my stuff in I paid the money I have the right
data.author: Aj Miller

data.text: Don't ask yourself. Assume it is OK. Then they have to take action. Im surprised sometimes how really nice hotels let you take the bikes in a room.
data.author: Andreas Madreiter

data.text: never had an issue
data.author: Dean Derek

data.text: Thank you for shares your experiences.
data.author: Hector Zhao

data.text: Still haven't been to one that said no.
data.author: Louie Garcia

data.text: No problem at US Marriott and Hilton properties. Ask for a first floor room so you don't have to deal with the elevator
data.author: Kate Schwarz

data.text: Just tell them it‚Äôs your therapy vehicle - it always works with my pet fish
data.author: Rob Tierney

data.text: I used to worry about it and then realized if you ask there is a greater chance they will say no out of reflex because it's an unknown for them. If you were in a wheelchair they would let you in so why not a a bike? As long as the bike looks clean and isn't dripping with shit then there should be no problem. All hotels have a luggage room that they should accommodate you with if not.
data.author: Peter Sheridan

data.text: If its easy to get to the room I just take it in without asking. If it's harder.. Lifts, tight spaces etc, I take off the wheels, pop them either side and clamp it together with a bungee then take it in like that without asking. I make sure it's fairly clean.
data.author: Jon Belt

data.text: Mostly no problem of it fits in the elevatorüòä
data.author: Miranda Dieleman

data.text: I started rolling it up to the counter with me to check in. Sometimes the argument gets heated. I stayed at a Hilton in Vienna last Fall where they were fine with it. Every place I stayed at after that I told them so.
data.author: Eric Knudstrup

data.text: Carry some thick extra large lawn and garden waste bags with you. Put the bike in it. Then you avoid any problems with dirt or grease getting all over and defuse any complaints from hotel staff.
data.author: Travis Reece

data.text: Yes!
data.author: Gerald Raton

data.text: I once stayed in a hotel in Puno in southern Peru. Had to get into something of a showdown with the check-in desk employees to be allowed to take my bike into my room. Later that night two other cyclists showed up with really expensive Rohloff equipped bikes. Management had them store bikes in the "locked" office. Next morning both bikes were gone. At least a $10,000 heists.... probably 5 years worth of salary for a Peruvian. Desk clerk from previous day was suddenly "on vacation and out of town". Sad ending to the couple's around the world plans. I always sleep with my bike.
data.author: Madhavananda Das Brssm

data.text: In China, yes. Even the bike got mud all over IT
data.author: Feng Tianshi

data.text: Most
data.author: Nige Tymm

data.text: This stopped all of the conversation at check in. A plastic bike bag at about 10 Euros on Wiggle. Easy.
data.author: Fiona Marie

data.text: Never had a problem... I stayed at a high end hotel a few times and their valet would tag it and store it for me.
data.author: Karl Menace

data.text: Yeah probably most .just don't bring it in with alot of mud or snow on tires .if I can't bring my bike inside I ain't staying.
data.author: Norbe Alatorre

data.text: As a hotel manager I encouraged it as I would see bikes on the back of the cars. I did not want them to come in and complain if there bike was stolen.
data.author: Steve Merchant

data.text: In the US almost always. Just refer to it as your roller bag.
data.author: Scott J. Mansfield

data.text: Yes
data.author: Silvio Duarte

data.text: When stopped taking my bike up at a fancy hotel or resort, I have always said, "It's okay. It's for the convention". Hasn't failed yet.
data.author: Barry Blumenkemper

data.text: I always appreciate the complementary bike wash and shop towels in the bathrooms.
data.author: Barry Blumenkemper

data.text: Yes
data.author: Joe Olgin

data.text: Pic of your bike!
data.author: Tam Thanh Nguyen

data.text: yes. for "normal" hotels. in the usa and canada anyway. you might find some issues at historic or luxury hotels or the occasional individually-owned place. b&bs generally frown on bikes in the rooms, but might often have lockups of varying quality. on one trip back to my home in nj from the fl keys, i made a stop to do the high bridge trail in farmville va. it was a dusty ride and i noticed the hotel had a coiled hose nearthe front door. i asked to borrow it to rinse my bike, they said yes, and later,after it dried (mostly), they thanked me for being a good guest. clean bikes are usually not an issue. i usually ask for a first floor room so as to avoid trying to cram into a small elevator. good luck.
data.author: Mike Bauer

data.text: We know how much you love your bike, that's why Koala Inn hotel, let you get into thr room your bike.
data.author: Luis Eduardo Guerrero

data.text: Yes they do
data.author: Beau Robacker

data.text: Don't ask just bring it in, if you can book in a motel, better. Enjoy!
data.author: Pol Igmen

data.text: I ask if they say no I just ride to the next hotel.
data.author: Amir De

data.text:
I learned that it's best to ask. Some will refuse, most will say yes, especially if they have a balcony, but I had also problems with a booking.com host that angrily knocked on my door the next morning and started taking picture of the bike with my stuff lying everywhere saying it's not a garage, etc. My fault for not asking, so always good to double check before booking.
Booking.com: The largest selection of hotels, homes, and vacation rentals
booking.com
data.author: Corina Aioni≈£oaie

data.text: We normally put the bikes in locked rooms close to the reception. üëçüèª Or in locked car parking. We prefer these solutions because the rooms often are small. üö¥‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
data.author: MerryBiking

data.text: I don't know, I've never asked them for permission
data.author: Rob Peterson

data.text: Two wheels or two legged phone or ask their policy simple each be different obviously
data.author: Rory Mitchell

data.text: Yes. I've only had an issue once, in a hotel in Bruges, Belgium. After a lengthy discussion I asked if luggage was allowed in the room. The concierge said "of course". I asked if he could give me three bin liners. I then put a wheel into each bin liner and the frame in a third, and called it "luggage". The bike ended up in my room, and the concierge complied with his hotel's policy. Everyone was satisfied.
data.author: Michael Bryant

data.text: Many years of bike travel under my belt. It‚Äôs extremely rare to have a hotel not allow you to either take a bike into your room or at least provide a safe location for it inside. Outright hostility happens sometimes, but I can count on my fingers the times where I was refused service. Once in a small town in Siberia, once in Cayenne, French Guyana, once in a motel in Fort Lauderdale, Florida (although they eventually made an exception for me). I had not reserved at any of these places, so it didn‚Äôt matter too much.
data.author: Robert Hart

data.text: Every hotel allows you to take your bike into the room if they don't know !!! ü§£
data.author: James Wreschinsky

data.text: That's now even a question! Hell yeah they do!
data.author: Cheryl L Boggs

data.text: Most definitely.
data.author: Cheryl L Boggs

data.text: I‚Äôd bring it into the room and to bed; but, my wife is not into that kind of ‚Äúlifestyle‚Äù. Check in advance; most do. I stayed at one that did not but, the place did have a secure gear locker behind the main counter where I felt the bike was safe. ‚úåÔ∏èü§™
data.author: Jay De La Sierra

data.text: Premier Inn have a policy to allow bikes in rooms.
data.author: George Grant

data.text: And can you bring your bike into the bed? Asking for a friend.....
data.author: Colin Gilbert

data.text: I have a so called ‚ÄûBike Condom‚Äù. That covers the bike and no dirt comes into the Hotel room.
data.author: Hans Dube

data.text: Yes‚Ä¶in U.S.
data.author: DP Mooney

data.text: Mine did!
data.author: Jack Wolhart

data.text: Only had a problem once‚Ä¶in a dump of a hotel in Mitchell, Oregon. Otherwise, nobody ever complained, anywhere (US, to be clear).
data.author: Ron Wechsler
